thread.section_title: NWAonline stories: High School Sports - Northwest Arkansas
thread.title: Gibson's best day good enough

title: Gibson's best day good enough
text:
Gibson's best day good enough By Tim Cooper Posted: October 16, 2015 at 2:35 a.m. By Rick McFarland Jonesboro’s Wil Gibson won the boys overall championship with a 3-under 72, defeating Fayetteville’s Luke Long and Rogers Heritage’s Jacob Winkel by four strokes. 
There was no keeping up with Jonesboro sophomore Wil Gibson on Thursday. 
Gibson birdied four of his first seven holes and cruised to a seven-stroke victory in the High School Overall Golf Championship at Pleasant Valley Country Club. 
Gibson finished with a 3-under 69 on the 6,785-yard course. 
Coming on the heels of last week's 12-stroke victory in the Class 6A state tournament at Searcy Country Club, Gibson admitted that he is playing well. 
"The best I've ever played is right now," Gibson said. "There are things I can do better, so there is room for improvement, but I think I'm playing real good golf." 
It would have been hard for anyone to match Gibson's putter Thursday. On the 147-yard, par-3 No. 2, Gibson drilled a 30-footer putt for birdie, the first of six on a breezy, hot day. Starting on No. 5, the sophomore hit three consecutive birdie putts, all of which were 10 feet or longer. 
"I never seen anyone roll in that many long putts in one round," said Fayetteville senior Luke Long, who played in Gibson's group and finished second with a 4-over 76. "He was amazing." 
Gibson figured he was in for a good round when his tee shot on the 216-yard, par-3 No. 5 landed on the green, 15 feet from the pin. 
"I had sprayed the ball to the right on that hole during my practice round," Gibson said. "I knew I couldn't do that again. ... There was a crosswind on that hole today, but I hit a good approach shot and put myself in a good spot to hit the putt." 
Gibson followed his birdie putt on No. 5 by making a 10-footer on No. 6 and a 15-footer on No. 7. 
"I don't think I could have done much better with my putter today," Gibson said. 
Rogers Heritage senior Jacob Winkle also shot a 76 on Thursday. Long won a one-hole playoff with Winkle to earn the second-place trophy. 
Long also birdied No. 6, but did so in an unconventional manner. Long chipped in from 45 feet moments after telling playing partner Caleb Kubacak of Maumelle that his shot was going in the hole. 
"I called that one before I chipped, but it was just a joke," Long said. "I told Caleb that I was going to make that shot. Of course, I had no idea I would do it." 
Long and the other 19 competitors in Thursday's field needed more miracle shots to compete with the eventual winner. Gibson fired an even-par 36 on the back nine, including another long-range birdie putt on the 358-yard, par-4 No. 16. 
"I started feeling too good about myself on the back half," Gibson said. "Then I made a couple of bogeys. Thankfully, I got that shot back on 16 and I started feeling better again." 
Thursday's tournament was sponsored by the Arkansas State Golf Association. 
Sports on 10/16/2015
